description:

How do these linguistic magicians listen and speak at the same time? How do they keep their cool when the stakes are so high, all while working directly with world leaders and business magnates? https://bit.ly/freeslkit_fflfast ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡· ğŸ“¯ ğŸª“ Each year, thousands of men from all over the world join the French Foreign Legion (LÃ©gion Ã©trangÃ¨re). Most come for adventure. Some for a better life. Many to earn a French passport.

But no matter their reason for enroling, ALL candidates must accomplish one key thing by the end of basic training if they want to receive any of the LÃ©gionnaire perks: learning enough French to function as a soldier!

It turns out that most of these men arrive at the recruitment center in France unable to speak a lick of French, and yet manage to get fluent enough in mere months to understand orders, describe the workings of their HK416F service rifle, and have conversations with fellow LÃ©gionnaires.

title: How U.S. Military Linguists Learn Languages Fast
description:
Learn a language faster with my FREE StoryLearning Fluency Blueprint ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://l.storylearning.com/free_SL_fluency-blueprint

United States Military Linguists are known for being among the fastest language learners in the world. But speed is certainly not the only goal. From gathering critical intelligence to supporting troops on the frontlines, a lot rests on the language skills of linguists in the U.S. Armed Forces.

So how do linguists in the U.S. Air Force, Army, Coast Guard, Marine Corps, and Navy learn the language skills they need to do their jobs? That is precisely what I wanted to find out, so I reached out to two graduates of the Defense Language Institute (DLI) in Monterey, California: Elle and Jack.

This video details the incredibly intense programmes these service members complete, including interesting techniques like â€œiso-immersionâ€ and â€œscream & scribbleâ€. While only a select few can attend DLI, there are some powerful principles in this video that ALL language learners can apply. Hooah!

title: How Can I Prepare To Travel Abroad In 1 Month?
description:
In this LIVE recording of the I Will Teach You A Language podcast, I answer @Kay Koopmans' question about how to prepare for moving abroad when you only have a month and don't yet speak any of the local language!

It's important to note that there's a big difference between learning enough language to survive in a short period of time, and developing high levels of fluency in the long-term. In today's video, I am focusing on the former (but understand that my advice differs significantly for the latter, as covered extensively in my other videos).

â“HAVE A QUESTION?

Have a question you'd like answered on YouTube or the podcast? Leave me a voice message here:
http://iwillteachyoualanguage.com/ask

ğŸ’¡ MY TIPS:

So if you are an absolute beginner, have only 1 month to prepare, and want to hit the ground running when you arrive abroad, here are the 4 things I recommend doing:

â‘  Get a good travel-focused textbook.

Textbooks get a bad rap in the polyglot world, but they can be useful for absolute beginners since someone has already gone to the trouble of putting together the most useful words, grammar, etc.
Get one focused on travel and daily situations and that has dialogues with audio recordings.

â‘¡ Focus on listening skills.

Donâ€™t just memorize things to say. You need to be able to actually understand things said back to you. So practice listening to the dialogues in your textbook over and over until you understand them easily.

â‘¢ Memorize useful words and phrases.

Pick out the most useful words and phrases from your textbook, and commit them to memory. Use whatever method works for you, may it be Anki, paper flashcards, etc.

â‘£ Get daily speaking practice.

Go on iTalki (https://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/italkidirect) or a similar tutoring site and schedule DAILY speaking practice. Do role plays for daily situations. Send your tutor the page or chapter from your textbook on that topic ahead of time.

ğŸ“š RESOURCES MENTIONED:

iTalki:
https://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/italkidirect)

Anki spaced repetition flashcards:
https://apps.ankiweb.net

My StoryLearningÂ® courses:
https://iwillteachyoualanguage.com/language-courses-select-your-language

â±TIMESTAMPS:

0:00 - Intro
0:26 - Tip #1: Get a good travel-focused textbook
3:55 - Tip #2: Focus on listening skills
5:24 - Tip #3: Memorize useful words and phrases
6:44 - Tip #4: Get daily speaking practice
8:54 - Recap of the 4 steps
13:40 - Live Q & A

title: How This Missionary Learned AMAZING Korean Through Hardcore Immersion
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_amazingkorean ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Imagine that you got a letter in the post announcing that you will be put on a plane to Korea in just 9 weeks, where you will stand on a street corner and talk to strangers about your faith IN KOREAN. Add to this the fact that you don't yet speak a single word in the language! ğŸ¤¯

That is precisely what my friend Derek Driggs experienced when he trained to be a missionary for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints at the Missionary Training Center (MTC) in Provo, Utah, before being sent to live in Korea for 2 years back in 2012.

In this video, I share how he reached such an impressive level in Korean, and what lessons you can apply in your own language learning adventures.

â€¼ï¸Important: All commentary in the video is about language learning, NOT religion. Please be respectful and keep that in mind when leaving any comments below.

Also, please note that though Derek was formerly an instructor at the Provo Missionary Training Center following his time in Korea, he is not an official representative or spokesperson for the MTC or the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints

title: How Moses McCormick learned 50+ languages! RIP @laoshu505000
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_inspiration  Moses McCormick was a prolific language learner and YouTuber who passed away recently. 

Incredibly, Moses spoke (to varying degrees) over 50 languages, and I wanted to pay tribute to him by making a video about how he learned languages - what drove him, and the techniques he used.

This wasn't an easy task, as Moses recorded 3,210 videos over his YouTube career. (This prolific activity gained him 1.2 million subscribers and over 180 million views.)

In other words, I had a lot of material to comb through! It would be impossible to sum up everything that Moses was about in just one video, but I tried my best, and I hope I did the task justice.

title: The Mass Sentence Method: Can it make you fluent? With Mike Campbell from @Glossika
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_sentence

â¡ï¸ Watch Part 2 with Mike interviewing me: https://youtu.be/tZclqsvUKcA
In this video, I talk with Mike Campbell, an American polyglot based in Taipei, Taiwan. Not only does he speak Mandarin Chinese to an amazing level, but he's also learned a number of other Chinese dialects and even some indigenous Taiwanese languages that are dangerously close to going extinct. Mike is also the founder of Glossika, an AI-based online language learning platform that uses mass exposure to sentences to help you learn vocabulary and grammar in-context. You know that I'm a big believer in learning through input and context, so I'm excited to dive more into how Mike approaches language learning.

title: Inclusive Spanish: A Simple Guide To Using & Understanding Lenguaje Inclusivo
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_inclusivespanish â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_inclusivespanish

Recently, I received a comment my Spanish Uncovered course from a student named Liana. Here's what she said:

"I know this is a challenging subject to broach, since Spanish is deeply gendered, but might Olly make a video or conduct a live talk addressing the invisiblization of non-binary transgendered folks by these binary-gendered pronouns and endings, and the movement to make Spanish more inclusive?"

As Liana says, one of the features of romance languages is that every single noun and verb is either based on, or changes with, gender, and that makes these languages rather inflexible when it comes to a fast-developing society around it!

It's a vital subject, but I'll also admit that it's outside my area of expertise, so I needed to do some brushing up myself!

So, I decided to ask my friend, SofÃ­a, a native Spanish-speaking writer and journalist to help me out. And she did just that!

SofÃ­a has created this fantastic video all about lenguaje inclusivo in Spanish. I hope you'll find it both enlightening and enjoyable!

In the video you'll learn:
- What lenguaje inclusivo is
- How to use it when you speak Spanish

title: Michel Thomas Method: Behind the Scenes of a Live 4-Day Recording to Learn Korean
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_koreanmethod â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼  https://bit.ly/freeslkit_koreanmethod

Full Blog Post: https://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/blog/michel-thomas-korean

Order the full Michel Thomas Korean course: https://amzn.to/2zwhTP9

I've taken on some ambitious language learning projects in the past, from learning Italian in London to a 2-week intensive Thai mission in Bangkok.

But Korean in four days?

Well, that's a little intimidating, even by my standards. Especially as it's considered a "super-hard language" for native English speakers.

Luckily, I was using the Michel Thomas method and had a lot of help along the way.

In this documentary, you'll watch the creation of the brand new Michel Thomas Korean course, with me as one of the students.

So how much did I learn in 4 days with my fellow student, Cerys? Did I survive this intense language learning mission? Check out the documentary to find out!

Featuring:

â€¢ Derek Driggs - Course Tutor
â€¢ Dr. Jieun Kiaer -Â Associate Professor in Korean Language and Linguistics, Oxford University
â€¢ Cerys Hadwin-Owen, Course Student (@ceryshadwinowen)

In this video, I interview writer, blogger and learning expert Scott Young.

Scott is a writer who undertakes interesting self-education projects, such as attempting to learn MIT's four-year computer science curriculum in twelve months and learning four languages in one year.

title: Principles of Language Learning with Lydia Machova | Part 5
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_lydiaprinciples â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_lydiaprinciples 

Welcome part 5 of my conversation with Lydia Machova, from LanguageMentoring.com (https://www.languagementoring.com)

In Today's Episode:
Make a Success of Long-Term Learning:

- I estimate it takes 500 hours (European language, B2 level, efficient time) = 2 years of 1 hours a day with breaks (2 months learning, 1 month break) ... but it's not necessary to learn non-stop! (My Swahili: 11 months, 5 of them off ğŸ™‚ ) - but I' m so much further ahead than a year ago!
 - Always make a plan, with a starting and end date - otherwise it's too scary.
 - Alternate methods: not one universal method for everyone, I keep alternating Goldlist and Anki, get tired of it after a few months
 - The island and the wave: when will I not lose the language anymore?
 - Two languages at once

title: Principles of Language Learning with Lydia Machova | Part 4
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_lydiaprinciples4 â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_lydiaprinciples4

Welcome part 4 of my conversation with Lydia Machovha, from LanguageMentoring.com (https://www.languagementoring.com/)

In Today's Episode:
To speak from day 1... or not?

 - Start with self-talk, then other speakers
 - Output is so much more important than the person you're talking to! 
 - Use other students, don't look for professional native speaker teachers
you won't learn mistakes from others (just negligible influence) - because lots of listening input!
 - Less stress with "non-native speakers"
 - Don't worry about making mistakes - this takes a change in mindset but it's possible (especially people from traditional school system)
 - What to talk about (esldisuccions.org)
 - Simplify what youâ€™re trying to say
 - The only way to improve speaking is to speak - not Duolingo, not reading, not grammar exercises

Welcome to this 5-part series, where I'm joined by my friend Lydia Machova, from LanguageMentoring.com (https://www.languagementoring.com/)

In Today's Episode:

Create time, don't wait till you have itâ€¦.

 - When I wake up, it's my first priority

 - A little testâ€¦ if you receive a phone call saying that a loved one had been taken to hospital, you would find the time to put everything else asideâ€¦

 - Language learning can also become a priority in your life, even if only for a short period

 - 30 min a day can change a lot. 1 hour a day means visible steady growth!

 - System is king! If you don't plan ahead, you need to rely on your willpower â€“ which is very difficult!

title: Should you take a break from language learning?
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:

Episode Summary:

â€¢ My life is full of examples of doing things better after a long break
â€¢ Our brains can only achieve so much by focused attention
â€¢ The Pomodoro technique works on this principle
â€¢ Focus mode vs diffuse mode
â€¢ Small scale - i.e. my daily writing habits in one day
â€¢ Large scale - i.e. learning patterns over many months
â€¢ Breaks are essential... even many months can be fine
â€¢ It works even better if you can take "study breaks" while also speaking or using the language a lot

title: Why immersion isn't a great language learning strategy for beginners
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Episode Summary:

â€¢ Immersion is always held up as the â€œholy grailâ€ of language learning
â€¢ Definition: Spending all day every day in a native-level environment
Itâ€™s not all itâ€™s cracked up to be

Survival bias is at play:
â€¢ Katzumoto: 10,000 hours of Japanese
â€¢ Gabriel Wyner: 8 weeks in Middlebury
â€¢ Your friend who went to China and was fluent in 3 months

â€¢ Immersion only works if you are able to go full-on enough, for long enough, and stay positive enough to make it to be successfulâ€¦ not practical for most people

As a study strategy, it leaves a lot to be desired:
â€¢ You donâ€™t understand anything
â€¢ Thereâ€™s no structure
â€¢ Not enjoyable

â€¢ My experiences with real immersion were not good
Paris, Japan, Egypt

â€¢ Immersion is much more effective when you can already hold you own

â€¢ Theory of â€œComprehensible inputâ€œ

â€¢ Whatâ€™s the opportunity cost?

title: Why you shouldn't listen to slow audio
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Are you having trouble finding authentic audio for your target language with matching transcripts?

Check out my brand new Conversations course that will help you transform your listening skills with story-based audio material
(http://iwillteachyoualanguage.com/conversations)

Episode Summary:

â€¢ News in Slow Spanish-type sites are becoming increasing popular

â€¢ With Yabla you can slow down the audio 

â€¢ But are these helpful, or dangerous?

â€¢ There are only two reasons you wonâ€™t understand something spoken:

A) You donâ€™t know the words/grammar
B) You canâ€™t understand fast speech

â€¢ If you slow down what youâ€™re listening to, youâ€™re not helping your listening, because itâ€™s not natural, and lacks the features of fast speech

â€¢ It simply gives you more time to process the information, i.e. think about the words used

â€¢ But is this the best way to learn new vocabularyâ€¦ listening to slow, unnatural audio?

â€¢ This = confusing / misunderstanding the problem, and can severely limited your ability to cope with real language

â€¢ Listening to stuff at your level (comprehensible input)
â€¢ Listen at natural speed, and use the transcript to help you understand.

PS -  I do sometimes slow down audio (Speater app), but itâ€™s always when Iâ€™m listening to stuff thatâ€™s too hard for me 

Caveat: Slowing down audio could be useful at the very beginning

Manifesto for Better Listening â€“ a blog post I wrote about listening skills (https://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/a-manifesto-for-better-listening/)

title: Stephen Krashen on Language Learning in the Polyglot Community
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast 

Dr. Stephen Krashen is one of the most influential figures in the field of second-language acquisition (SLA), and has made a major contribution to the way we now think about language teaching and learning. 

I was delighted to get the opportunity to sit down with Dr. Krashen in Montreal to discuss a range of topics, in particular the extent to which his theories of language acquisition can be observed in the learning techniques of polyglots - people who learn multiple language. 

In this fascinating interview, you'll hear about: 
â€¢ Krashenâ€™s background with music, and the relationship between music and language learning
â€¢ Do language teachers have an obligation to learn languages themselves?
â€¢ The languages that Krashen speaks himself
â€¢ The role of â€œcomprehensible inputâ€ in language learning
â€¢ What does he think of the polyglot community?
â€¢ Whatâ€™s the one language mystery that Krashen would like to see solved?

For a full summary of the interview, please visit the original blog post: 
http://iwillteachyoualanguage.com/krashen

Get in touch with Dr. Krashen:
â€¢ Twitter: @skrashen
â€¢ Website: www.sdkrashen.com

- - -

title: IWTYAL 188: What are the benefits of monolingual flashcards?
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast 

Charlotte asks: â€œWhatâ€™s your opinion on removing English from flashcards altogether?

Full Transcript: (http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/monolingual-flashcards/)

Episode Summary:
 - Arguments for having flashcards entirely in the target language:
 - Avoid translation
 - Learn to think in the target language
 - Increased exposure to target language
 - â€œLearn like a childâ€

Arguments for having pictures on your flashcards:
 - Visual memory is stronger than auditory memory
 - Wyner: â€œItâ€™s much easier to learn a word off of a picture card youâ€™ve made yourself than off of a translation card you downloaded in someone elseâ€™s deck.â€ = false equivalence

My response to this:
 - Translation is inevitable, and also very useful! (The more languages I acquire, the more I use contrastive analysis to learn faster.)
 - Parallels with learning like children are misguided â€“ weâ€™re not children, we have study skills
 - Flashcards entirely in the target language are soon â€œlearntâ€, thereby negating the benefit of any increased exposure.
 - Visuals are helpful, but are so time consuming as to make the creation of flashcards a burden.
 - Elaborate systems for flashcards misunderstand the purpose of SRS as a learning tool. Setting up flashcards with pictures and peripheral info in the target language, in an attempt to make them a kind of learning tool is not only highly inefficient, but also deprives you of time spent with the whole language

My thoughts on a smart approach to using flashcards:
 - Flashcards are for practising output, not input
In other words, flashcards are for practising the recall of stuff youâ€™ve already learnt
 - The role of English in the flashcards is as a prompt â€“ your task is then to recall the word or phrase in the target language.
 - Images are indeed powerful, but are best created in your mind (i.e. mnemonics)
 - Itâ€™s vital for flashcards not to become burdensome â€“ Keep it simple!
 - The potential for memory exists firmly within your mind â€“ the extent to which you employ your brainpower and imagination when you attempt to learn new vocabulary determines how well you remember it.
 - To that extent â€“ the spaced repetition build into flashcards offers you an opportunity to reinforce the associations you have already made, rather than the source of learning itself.

(http://iwillteachyoualanguage.com/freememorycourse)

title: IWTYAL 185: How to make your sentences less English
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast 

Meg asks: â€œHow can I make my Russian sentences less English?â€

Full Transcript: (http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/make-sentences-less-english/)

Episode Summary:
 - The challenge youâ€™re facing is learning to express ideas the way a 
 - Russian would
 - Itâ€™s not just a linguistic thing â€“ itâ€™s a cultural thing. Compare: Good Morning / ãŠã¯ã‚ˆã†ã”ã–ã„ã¾ã™
 - Thereâ€™s no shortcut to doing this â€“ itâ€™s a long, gradual process
 - If you want to express yourself like a Russian, you need to spend a lot of time with Russian â€“ listening, reading, speaking
 - The process you need to practise is how to take an idea, and construct a sentence the way a Russian would. In order to achieve this, any exercise that helps you slow down the process and get feedback on your efforts can be helpful.

Try:
1. Reverse translation (see below)
2. Your teacher can ask you: â€œHow do you say ___ in Russian?â€ and then correct you
3. Talk to yourself in Russian as you walk around the house
4. But ultimately, a lot of listening and reading is the best policy!

title: IWTYAL 184: My students have holes in their grammar
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Ferdinand asks: "How do I repair holes in my students' grammar?"

Episode Summary:

 - How holes in your grammar can develop
 - Different roles for the teacher:
 - Teach what you know is right
 - Teach what the student expects
 - Raising awareness is the only way to help students self-monitor and fix their own mistakes
 - If students resist basic grammar exercises, look for another way...

How to raise awareness and encourage self-monitoring:
 - Talk to them about their goals, and how better grammar would help
"Stealth grammar"
 - Record the student and have them listen back
 - Write two sentences on the board, ask: "What's the difference?"
 - Set writing tasks instead of speaking tasks - scaffold their language and highlight opportunities for better grammar

Resources Mentioned In Today's Episode:

19 quick changes you can make today that will make you a better language teacher

Balen asks: â€œIs it possible to become fluent in a language only by listening?â€

Episode Summary:
 - No, you canâ€™t become fluent only by listening.
 - The Silent Period
 - Children listen for years, soaking things up, but still take years of practise to produce coherent English
 - Learning English by watching TV
 - Immigrants are often silent for yearsâ€¦listening instead

However, listening is the most important skill, and I find myself spending more and more time working on it:
 - The role of time
 - Active vs Passive Listening

Rafael asks: â€œHow can I stop hesitating when I speak English?â€

Full Transcript: (http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/hesitating-speaking/)

Episode Summary:

Hesitation happens either when:
 - You donâ€™t have the vocabulary you need
 - You donâ€™t know how to express something
 
Speaking fluidly, without hesitation, comes with a lot of practice:
 - Practice more regularly with native speakers
 - Increase your vocabulary on common topics, focusing on full sentences
 - Spend more time with the â€œwhole languageâ€ â€“ reading and listening with transcripts
 - Learn monologues and rehearse them thoroughly
 - Try shadowing

Denise asks: â€œIs now a good time to learn Italian?â€

Episode Summary:
 - Thereâ€™s rarely a â€œright timeâ€
 - I usually suggest getting a language to an Upper-Intermediate level (B2) before starting another one
 - However, Italian and Portuguese are closely related. You might not have to do as much study as you think.
 - It might also be easier than learning English
 - Spend a bit of time each day simply listening and reading to basic Italian. You donâ€™t have to do any speaking, or heavy study, just start to put it on the map
 - Time will do the rest!

title: IWTYAL 175: I just smile and pretend I can understand
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Gabrielle asks: â€œWhen I donâ€™t understand, I often just smile, nod, and pretend I do. How can I stop this?â€

Full Transcript: (http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/pretend-to-understand/)

Episode Summary:
 - Is it normal to pretend you understand?
 - Every language learning journey starts like this
 - Persistence is the name of the game

In terms of stages, hereâ€™s how I see it:
 - Lower level: You still have a lot to learn, so donâ€™t be surprised if you donâ€™t understand. Keep studying. Have conversations with sympathetic listeners.

 - Higher level: This is the stage where you need to get used to the vocabulary of everyday life, especially if youâ€™ve been in â€œstudy modeâ€ for a long time. Speak as much as possible, and focus on the situation/conversation, not the language. Record your conversations and analyse them later.

Remember:
 - You donâ€™t need to understand everything
 - Keeping the conversation going is key
 - Make general points
 - Tell stories
 - Ask questions

Improve your English, learn more vocabulary, and have fun with these eight exciting English short stories! In this book you will find:

title: IWTYAL 174: Should I rely on Google Translate?
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast 

Yuta asks: â€œShould I be relying on Google Translate?â€

Full Transcript: (http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/rely-google-translate/)

Episode Summary:

1. Effective language learning means learning to communicate within your means
2. The problem with relying on Google Translate is that you stop relying on yourself
3. Paraphrasing is a key speaking skill, and you develop it by learning to communicate in spite of a lack of vocabulary
4. HelloTalk is great for practising stuff you already know, but not necessarily for developing fluency
5. I would devote time instead to live conversation
6. While talking, make a note of the things you canâ€™t say, and learn them later

title: IWTYAL 173: How many hours a week do you study?
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Selman asks: â€œHow many hours a week do you study?â€

Full Transcript: (http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/how-many-hours-study/)

Episode Summary:

1. Hereâ€™s what I aim for: Focused study every weekday morning (1 hour), sporadic flashcards + listening during the day (0-60 mins), at least 3 speaking sessions a week (30-60 minutes)
2. A rough total is around 5 hours study + 3 hours speaking
3. Add on top of that watching TV, reading books, going out etc
4. However, I often go for days without studying, and donâ€™t often stick to this schedule, but it tends to come back to this
5. Remember that the success you have depends much more on the range of activities you do â€“ speaking, reading etc. Are those considered studying?
6. With my stronger languages like Spanish, Japanese etc, I donâ€™t study them any more, I just use them

What happened to me:
 - I learnt to say a bunch of things, but never really understood the language
 - I never spent enough time listening
 - After moving to Japan, I continued studying, gradually building up my knowledge, but it took forever
 - It wasnâ€™t until I began speaking very often that I really began to crack Japanese, and become comfortable with itâ€™s logic

My suggested plan of attack:
 - Avoid lessons at the start, unless you can find a good teacher
 - Choose a textbook you like and work through it, focusing on the dialogues
 - Learn hiragana and katakana immediately
 - Once youâ€™ve completed your textbook, look for an iTalki tutor, and set up 2-3 speaking sessions a week
 - Do as much listening as possible!

title: IWTYAL 167: How to stop translating in your head
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Arnie asks: â€œHow can I stop translating in my head when people speak to me in French?â€

Full Transcript:
(http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/stop-translating-in-your-head/)

Episode Summary:
 - See episode 87 for a previous answer to this topic
 - Translating in your head is a very common problem
 - Thereâ€™s no quick fix I can give you, only some encouragement and a helpful way of thinking about the problem
 - To state the obvious: When you understand whatâ€™s being said in French, you have no reason to translate
 - Therefore, the more you improve, the less you translate
 - This is good to remember, as it helps you realise itâ€™s a gradual process
 - For me, translating tends to be a grammar issue
 - My Cantonese right now â€“ often Iâ€™ll understand something in Cantonese, with no translation. Sometimes, Iâ€™ll come across a sentence thatâ€™s grammatically different and Iâ€™ll need to translate it in my head in order to make sense of it. This dies away over time, as I improve.

Key points:
 - Spend more time listening and reading
 - Grow your vocabulary
 - Start using monolingual dictionaries
 - Do more of your daily activities in French

Some deeper approaches to studying:
 - When you learn new grammar, focus on grammar patterns, not individual verbs
 - With these new grammar patterns, try to get into the head of a native speaker, and feel the way an idea is being expressed â€“ the attitude or feeling â€“ rather than focus on the English translation
 - Work with full sentences in your study, not single words

Todayâ€™s Quote:
â€œYou donâ€™t learn a language, you get used to it.â€ â€“ Katsumoto

title: IWTYAL 166: Adapting the Memory Palace technique
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Fletcher asks: â€œCan I adapt the traditional memory palace technique?â€

Episode Summary:
 - What is a memory palace? (The story of Simonides)
 - Choose a building youâ€™re familiar with
 - Take words you want to remember
 - Place them around the room
 - Create mnemonic with location + action
 - Practise recalling the words by walking through the memory palace sequentially

Two key features:
1. Location â€“ create a mnemonic using the location itself (e.g. the sofa)
2. Recall â€“ practise recall by walking through the memory palace

Fletcher asks if you can substitute the building or room, for the handlebars of a bicycleâ€¦
- You can do anything!
 - The key to making the memory palace word is vivid imagery, so if that works for you, then great!
 - Make sure you think about the key elements of location and recall.
 - Try out your variation technique and compare it to the more traditional memory palace

title: IWTYAL 165: What is the ideal language learning environment?
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Sonia asks: â€œWhatâ€™s the ideal language learning environment?â€

Full Transcript:
(http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/ideal-language-environment/)

Episode Summary:
1. Thereâ€™s no such thing as the ideal, or best, language learning environment

2. Learning to speak a language is heavily linked to affective factors â€“ your feelings and how you react to the environment around you

3. You can be very analytical, and conclude that complete immersion after a minimum of study is the â€œmost efficient wayâ€â€¦ but only if youâ€™re happy in that environment

4. When I look back on my language learning story, my success has been heavily linked to my environment (e.g. Spanish friends in London vs isolation in Japan)

5. The question I ask myself most when I learn languages now is: â€œHow does this language make sense in the context of the lifestyle that I enjoy?â€ (e.g. In Hong Kong I didnâ€™t have great working conditions, so my language learning suffered as a result)

6. If your French is still low-level, you still have a lot of work to do. You can do this naturally through speaking with people, or you can do it through formal study (or some combination of the two)

7. Isolating yourself in rural France is a big gamble, where you and your personality will determine whether you succeed or not

8. The question is not: â€œIs this the best way?â€ The question should be: â€œIs this the best way for me?â€œ

9. I donâ€™t know what your commitment to staying in France is, but donâ€™t be afraid to follow the path that makes you happier â€“ life is about more than language learning

10. In your specific situation, I would accept the reality that interacting socially is hard, and seek out a language partner or tutor (e.g. iTalki) who can help you get dedicated practice and build up your confidence

11. It might seem perverse to pay someone to help you while youâ€™re in France, but it might be a smart move.

Todayâ€™s Quote:
"I have been and still am a seeker, but I have ceased to question stars and books; I have begun to listen to the teaching my blood whispers to me."
â€“ Hermann Hesse

description:

Eleanor asks: â€œHow can I maintain my Spanish after university?â€

Full Transcript: (http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/maintain-language-after-university/)

Episode Summary:
1. Learning vs maintenance
2. When is maintenance necessary?
3. Being realistic
4. Richard Simcottâ€™s approach (as described in Language Learning Foundations) (https://learn.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/llf-main-order-page)
5. What I do personally to maintain my languages

Tips for maintaining languages at an advanced level:
 - Reading books you like
 - Watching movies, TV or listening to podcasts
 - Attending events
 - Hanging out with friends
 - Studying in the language
 - Language exchanges using a foreign language (e.g. Spanish/Korean as a native English speaker)

title: IWTYAL 163: Learning Cantonese after Mandarin
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Chris asks: â€œHow should I start learning Cantonese, given that I already speak Mandarin?â€

Full Episode Transcript:
(http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/cantonese-after-mandarin/)

Episode Summary:

 - Cantonese is to Mandarin what Cockney is to English
 - Itâ€™s a highly developed, unique language that is considered a spoken language
 - When Cantonese speakers write things down, they normally use standard Chinese

So what does this mean for a Mandarin speaker who wants to learn Cantonese?

 -  At the risk of oversimplifying, your major task is to learn a large amount of Cantonese-specific vocabulary, including the different pronunciation and more tones
 - While there is more to it than that (different grammar structures, sentence particles etc), the two languages are close enough that your existing knowledge of Mandarin will transfer very well, help you notice any differences and slowly adjust
 - You wonâ€™t have many new linguistic concepts to learn, itâ€™s more a question of getting use to the specific ways Cantonese speakers express themselves
 - Itâ€™s not the same task as learning a Chinese dialect from scratch as a foreigner

What about the practical considerations?

 - Because youâ€™re going to get so much â€œfor freeâ€, you should start by doing a lot of listening and let time do the work
 - Use resources where the audio comes with written Cantonese, so you can start associate the characters you already know with new sounds
 - Iâ€™ve been told the best Cantonese resources are written in Mandarin, so if you can cope, go with those!
 - Given your experience, I would spend a few months simply working through textbook dialogues and noticing as much as possible
 - To master the language, youâ€™ll need to arrange your life in a way that allows you to speak regularly (see episode 153)(http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/learn-languages-abroad/) your progress is going to depend on your ability to make those lifestyle changes

title: IWTYAL 161: Should I Use Formal or Informal Language?
description:
â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Chris asks: â€œShould I speak formally or informally in Turkish?â€

In this episode:
1. Every language has itâ€™s convention as to when and where you should speak formally or informally
2. Iâ€™ve found myself resisting speaking formally in other languages, and Iâ€™ve always been curious why that is
3. What Iâ€™ve learnt is that my â€œdefaultâ€ is informal, because thatâ€™s the way we speak English
4. Once you understand the cultural significance of formal and informal speech in the language youâ€™re learning, it will make your decision much easier

Japanese:
 - Ultra polite: omeshi-agari ni narimasen ka
 - Polite: meshi-agarimasen ka OR taberaremasen ka
 - Normal: tabemasu ka
 - Informal: taberu?

Spanish:
 - TÃº is standard in most places for speaking to someone your age or below
 - But in Colombia, Usted is used within the family, as a cultural mark of respect and affection

French:
 - â€œJe peux vous tutoyer?â€
 
The problem in your case may be that youâ€™re not using Turkish enough to develop a gut feel for what is appropriateâ€¦
 - Once youâ€™re using the language regularly, youâ€™ll get it!
 - Remember that speaking politely, but with a warm smile, can be extremely endearing and doesnâ€™t have to be stiff
 - Watch TV and movies and pay attention just to that
 - A good rule of thumb is to use the polite form
 - But it never really mattersâ€¦ you get a free pass as a foreigner!

Quote Of The Day:

"Be polite; write diplomatically; even in a declaration of war one observes the rules of politeness."
-Otto von Bismarck

Valentin asks: â€œIâ€™m at intermediate level in Russian. How can I grow my vocabulary?â€

In this episode:
1. Thereâ€™s no quick solution â€“ you have a large amount of vocabulary to learn, and that takes time
2. Firstly, make sure you can read Russian. Itâ€™s not too hard, and not being able to read is a handicap
3. â€œI canâ€™t read books or read articlesâ€ â€“ maybe not, but you can find material thatâ€™s graded

Tools that can help you readâ€¦
1. LingQ
2. ReadLang
3. My book of short stories in Russian 
(http://amzn.to/2jeDLrF)

Alsoâ€¦
 - Find speaking partners and use Russian socially â€“ in Japan, speaking with others as much as possible was how I grappled upward to fluency
 - Donâ€™t ignore the option of taking classes â€“ it can be a good, systematic way to improve
 - Avoid using prepared lists or flashcard decks

Overall:
 - The principle is to grow your vocabulary using material you enjoy. Why? Because by staying motivated, youâ€™ll ultimately get more exposure.
 - Try to enjoy the â€œstruggleâ€ â€” itâ€™s your best friend!

Keeping conversations going as a beginner:

 - You might prefer a more structured approach

title: IWTYAL 157: Keeping a language alive after returning home
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast  

Libby asks: "I've recently returned home after a year in Germany. How can I keep up my German?"

In this episode:
 - It's normal for your language to go through "seasons"
 - My Thailand experience, how I feel about it now, and why I'm not worried
 - How I learnt Spanish and Portuguese... and didn't use them for years!
 - The maturing of my Japanese
 - Having lived abroad and experienced what it's like to live a language, going back to studying might feel wrong to you
 - You're doing all the right things... reading, speaking etc

So try to answer the question: "What role does German play in my life now?"
A new language ultimately exists to use it
Personally, I don't study my older languages much (if at all). I just use them.
What I do to keep my languages alive:

 - Actively search out friends using language exchange sites
 - Attend meetups
 - Sign up to cultural activities
 - Travel to the country
 - Invent language-related projects to keep the language in my attention
 - Run my own Meetup in London (http://iwillteachyoualanguage.com/polyglotpub)

title: IWTYAL 155: How long should I study with same material?
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast  

Clay asks: â€œFor how long should I use the same material?â€

In this episode:
 - One of the most destructive language habits is jumping from one material to the next
 - Usually, my advice is to stick with ONE thing, simply to guard against the â€œbutterflyâ€ problem
 - â€œDonâ€™t let the great be the enemy of the goodâ€

When Iâ€™m studying, I usually have a few different strands to my learning:
1. Speaking on a regular basis
2. Flashcard review of vocabulary
3. Study time

In my study time, I tend to do one thing over and over, until I get bored.

 - I wonder why youâ€™re asking this question?
 - You should know deep down if the activity youâ€™re doing is productive or not
 - If you feel itâ€™s productive, keep going!
 - You will certainly lose motivation to do it sooner or laterâ€¦ wait till that time! (For me itâ€™s usually 3 weeks)
 - If you feel itâ€™s not productive, stop immediately and try something else
 - Try to avoid FOMO â€“ providing youâ€™re speaking, learning vocabulary, and doing other holistic activities, you wonâ€™t be missing out on anything!

Resources Mentioned in This Episode:
â€œSprintsâ€ â€“ My 3-week approach to studying language material

title: IWTYAL 154: How to teach languages to children
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Chen asks: â€œHow can I teach my child a foreign language without a native environment?â€

In this episode:
 - Studies comparing school education systems donâ€™t find any benefits   to starting school tuition before the age of 11. However, this is an indictment of the education system more than anything
 - It is possible to teach children many languages at the same time
 - Itâ€™s always good to follow the childâ€™s interests, but since children change their tastes so frequently, I would pick the language you want him/her to learn, and focus on that over the long-term

The ideal scenario is as follows:
 - Set aside one hour a day for the language
 - If possible, bring in an au-pair or nanny to interact with the child for that time (â€œOne Person One Languageâ€)
 - If that is not possible, learn the language yourself, and teach him/her as you go
 - Use the same teaching methods you would use in your mother tongue â€“ songs, games, cartoons
 - Be VERY patient, and donâ€™t expect quick results

Resources Mentioned in This Episode:
 - Tetsu Yung on the Actual Fluency Podcast â€“ raising multilingual children (http://actualfluency.com/afp-s3e15-tetsu-yung-raising-multilingual-children/0

title: IWTYAL 153: Tips to learn languages abroad
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

In this episode, I discuss learning languages abroad.

In this episode:
 - Moving abroad to learn a language isnâ€™t always as easy as it seems
 - The need to feel comfortable can lead to decisions that arenâ€™t  helpful for language learning

What Iâ€™ve been doing in Hong Kong:
 
1. Talking to people on the street is neither easy nor productive. Create dedicated opportunities to speak: 
ConversationExchange.com, MyLanguageExchange.com

2.  Learning local vocabulary for daily life is the biggest benefit to living abroad: Use flashcards to store what you learn

3. Keep an ongoing record of phrases you want to use, and ask someone later (again, I use flashcards for this)

4. You only need a couple of good friends to create a perfect learning environment â€“ go out as much as possible

5. Use commuting time for study

6. Use all dead time for revision

7. Donâ€™t stop studying!

8. Look for ways to involve yourself in the language â€“ Iâ€™m creating my own materials

Resources Mentioned in This Episode:

(http://conversationexchange.com/MyLanguageExchange.com)

title: IWTYAL 145: Staying Safe in Language Exchanges
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Ashley asks: â€œHow do you stay safe when doing language exchanges?â€

In this episode:

 - Making connections is the real joy of language learning
 - My perspective as a man
 - Itâ€™s undeniable that some people are looking for more â€“ just like real life!
 - Just as in real life, you need to stay aware
 - Corresponding in advance, talking about the terms of your exchange, and trusting your gut is probably best
 - Beyond that, if youâ€™re meeting online (such as Skype), youâ€™re safe â€“ just donâ€™t reveal any personal details
 - You could use a separate Skype name and Gmail address, but that might not be the foundation of a good friendship
 - If meeting face-to-face, itâ€™s almost certainly fine, just meet in a public place
 - However, Iâ€™m not best qualified to advise on thisâ€¦ leave your comments please!

title: 5 Language Questions For Lindsay Dow!
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast 

In this video, I put five of your language learning questions to Lindsay Dow, of LindsayDoesLanguages.com!

To hear more from Lindsay, please subscribe to her YouTube channel here:
https://www.youtube.com/c/lindsaydowlanguages

The questions are:

Alan: Don't you think it's a tad odd, that in South America, there's a-lot of countries that speak Spanish, and then there's Brazil that speak Portuguese?"

Adam: How should I design a self-study program or find a self-study program if I'm not sure if I'm an advanced beginner or intermediate learner?

Noha: Is it possible to learn relatively similar languages ( e.g Spanish and Italian) simultaneously without mixing them up?

Andy: I'd like to ask how you feel emotionally connected to languages you have learnt. Do you have favourite languages? Some you just enjoy more? Does this help maintain stronger lifelong motivation for certain languages? And on the other hand do you get to a point where you realise, hey this language project has run its course?

title: Learn Thai Challenge: Masterclass with Stu Jay Raj
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast  

We're at the end of week 1 of our project to learn Thai, and we were fortunate enough to be invited to join famous polyglot and Thai expert Stu Jay Raj for the afternoon. 

What you'll see in this video is something special...

Stu Jay walks us through our Day 4 video, and points out lots of interesting features of our Thai. Here's the video for your reference: https://youtu.be/4CiPDSX3rcA

This will be especially interesting for you if you're also learning Thai, as there are lots of mistakes he points out that are typically made by foreigners. 

Stu Jay himself is a wealth of knowledge, and I highly recommend you check out all his resources if you're learning Thai:

Cracking Thai Fundamentals Book: http://stujay.com/product/cracking-thai-fundamentals-book/

Cracking Thai Unlimited Videl Course:
http://stujay.com/product/cracking-thai-unlimited-subscription-package/

Visit Stu's YouTube channel:
https://www.youtube.com/user/stujaystujay

Visit Jan's YouTube channel:

title: Foreign Language Study Sequences #6: Understanding Native Speakers
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast  

This video is part of a series on how to use your core study time to learn a language quickly. This video focuses on the best way to study the dialogues you find in your textbooks.

Textbook dialogues are one of the staples of language learning. Most textbooks have them, and they're a great way to learn a language by studying real language.

However, what's the best way to study them effectively? How do you make sure you actually learn the words and phrases you find in them? And how can you avoid wasting your time?

For the full blog post accompanying this video, click here:
http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/studying-dialogues/

For more on my exact study routine, check out:
http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/my-crazy-5am-language-routine/

This video is part of a series on how to use your core study time to learn a language quickly. This video focuses on the best way to study the dialogues you find in your textbooks.

Textbook dialogues are one of the staples of language learning. Most textbooks have them, and they're a great way to learn a language by studying real language.

However, what's the best way to study them effectively? How do you make sure you actually learn the words and phrases you find in them? And how can you avoid wasting your time?

description:

Olly Richards and Luca Lampariello discuss the question: "Can technology help you learn a language?" 

New language apps and websites are springing up every day. But does technology actually help you learn a language faster and better?

In this fascinating conversation, Luca and I discuss our experience learning multiple languages, and how much technology has helped us.

- What Luca's friends told him about their technology habits

- Gamification can help get people started in language learning, but is this a good thing?

- What was language learning like before the internet?

title: English guy speaking Egyptian Arabic after 6 months
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

I've been living in Egypt and learning Egyptian Arabic for about 6 months now, so I wanted to make a short video to document my progress.

In this video, which was partly prepared, I talk about how many Arabic learners consider it to be an extremely difficult language to learn. 

In my experience, although undoubtedly challenging, Arabic is not particularly difficult when compared to other languages. My last two languages were Japanese and Cantonese, both of which were equally challenging.

The one genuinely difficult area of Arabic, though, is grammar. Learning Arabic grammar is a huge task, and one that takes many years to perfect, proving too much even for native speakers.

However, I don't let this problem hold me back, because *speaking* is my main priority, and I'm able to communicate perfectly well even with occasionally inaccurate grammar. 

Olly speaking Japanese:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cv09DoKrJPQ

Olly speaking Cantonese:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3QRVpNbNzK8

Check out this interview with me filmed in the streets of Cairo:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5slVHy2JmcQ

How to learn the Arabic alphabet in 28 minutes:
https://youtu.be/uDXQztbFx-4?list=PLQJscr8iS4eHs416LKWnBBMknvEdsLYss

http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/resources/arabic-language-resource-page/

title: 8 study hacks you can use when youâ€™re too busy to learn a language
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Are you too busy to learn a language? Do you always find it hard to make time to study? 

Me too. 

In this video I'm going to lift the lid on a typical day, and let you look over my shoulder as I study languages in all kinds of different places over the course of 24 hours. 

There are eight "techniques" in the video. The point here is not to show you any groundbreaking new language learning techniques - in fact you'll notice that all of these are pretty simple!

The point is to demonstrate just what's possible if you use a variety of techniques and mediums.

If you're busy (and who isn't!), you probably find it hard to sit down and study for a whole hour in the evening. 

Studying regularly throughout the day is the solution for this. Use the 5, 10 or 15-minute blocks that inevitably crop up during the course of a day to get a short "language fix"!

15 minutes might not sound like a lot, but they really start to add up over the course of a week, month and year. Also, many language learners find that studying regularly is more effective than studying in a single block, because your brain gets used to jumping back into gear at short notice!

Techniques and resources mentioned in this video:

1. Listening to music
Spotify - http://spotify.com
Youtube - http://youtube.com

2. Flashcard apps
Flashcards Deluxe - http://flashcardsdeluxe.com

3. Listening to dialogues
Glossika Mass Sentences - http://iwillteachyoualanguage.com/glossika

4. Self-talk
Only need yourself!

5. Instant messaging
http://lang-8.com
http://hellotalk.com

6. Speaking sessions with a tutor or language partner
http://iwillteachyoualanguage.com/italki

7. Foreign language TV!
http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/watching-movies-for-language-learning/

8. Language videos
http://fluentu.com
http://youtube.com

So, which of these ideas can you take and fit into your routine?

title: Is your vocabulary notebook out of control?
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

How to memorise words: http://bit.ly/1Dnxdfk
Do you have vocabulary notebooks that are out of control?

When you're learning a new language, you probably write lots of things down. But do you have a proper system for actually learning all the stuff you put in your notebooks?

This video shows you my system for dealing with large amounts of vocabulary that you simply can't learn.

It's all about taking control of your learning. You don't need to learn every word that you ever hear. In fact, learning a small number of genuinely useful words in your target language can make a huge difference to your ability to speak it.

However, we typically end up sabotaging our learning by trying to take on too much...and not learning anything as a result! 

For more on using flashcards to memorise vocabulary, see this video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wkddc5gubf4

Want to learn to memorise more words? Click here:
http://bit.ly/1Dnxdfk

This is the flashcard app I used in the video:
http://flashcardsdeluxe.com/Flashcards/

Also check out Luca's video on the same topic:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XDfUzIAyzRw

In fact, the variety Yuki has learned, and used in the video, was Spanish Sign Language, or Lengua de Signos EspaÃ±ola (LSE). It really sucks.

Youâ€™re learning a new language, and it finally comes time to try it out with some native speakers!

So, you pluck up the courage, walk over to them, try your best to say something nice.

They look at youâ€¦

They think for a secondâ€¦

â€¦and they reply in English!

You want to keep talking in your new language, but you also donâ€™t want to offend them. So you smile and switch back to English, trying to hide your disappointment.

How can you stop this happening?

I answer that question in this video in Spanish.

title: How I learnt Egyptian Arabic in Week 1
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast

Read the blog post here: http://www.iwtyal.com/egyptian-arabic-week-1-summary/

This is some of what I did in my first week of learning Egyptian Arabic.

Here's what I did this week:

- Learnt some phrases in Arabic, made them into a short self-introduction, and recorded it (video below).
- Used an online Egyptian Arabic dictionary to generate a list of vocabulary about myself (video below).
- Started my first flashcard deck by copying a selection of words and phrases across and starting to learn them (video below).
- Wrote out an extended introduction on iTalki using this new vocabulary and had it (extensively) corrected.
- Arranged a 30-minute speaking session with a native speaker on day 5 (but teacher didn't turn up!)
- Listened to Pimsleur Egyptian Arabic 1-4 in the car everyday.

Tools used:
Dictionary: http://www.lisaanmasry.com/
Listening practice in the car: Pimsleur Egyptian Arabic
Speak in a week: http://www.fluentin3months.com/speak-in-a-week/
Google Docs: http://docs.google.com
iTalki: http://iwtyal.com/italki
http://www.omniglot.com/language/phrases/arabic_egyptian.php

http://www.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/cantoneseconversations

....

Learning Cantonese has been the most challenging language-learning experience for me so far. I live in Doha, and there are no Cantonese speakers around here! This has made finding people to communicated with a top priority, and quite hard to do.

Also, the fact that Cantonese is a spoken language has made the learning process a strange one. What do you do when you hardly even see your language written down?

I'm pretty pleased with my level after 1 year, especially given the fact that I've only really studied for around 15 minutes a day on average. I think I've got a good command of the 6 tones of Cantonese, which is good because it was a priority for me. I've also got used to speaking with people and can hold really interesting conversations, providing they're on reasonably familiar topics. (No politics yet!)

Areas to work on in the future include building my vocabulary way beyond where it's at now, and learning written Chinese. 

Moving forward, I'm going to prioritise speaking over other things. This means arranging regular language exchanges or tutor sessions, and trying hard to keep it consistent.

title: Portuguese Video: The Secret to an Awesome Accent
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:

Stories are the best way I have found to learn Portuguese (and the 7 other languages I speak). Forget the boring textbooks and time-wasting apps! Learn Portuguese the natural, effective way with my Portuguese Uncovered course.
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/portugueseuncoveredl1

How can you get a great accent when speaking a foreign language? 

There are two parts to consider if you want to have a good accent that helps you communicate effectively with native speakers.

Read the full post here: http://www.thepolyglotdream.com/developing-an-awesome-accent/

Firstly, you need a good understanding of the phonetics of the language you're learning. Take the time to learn to produce the basic sounds of the language correctly, and get help from a native speaker to make sure you're on the right track.

But after that, the only way to really develop an effective accent is to get out there and interact with people. I was lucky when I went to Brazil in that I already had a group of friends who I could hang out with. 

By spending lots of time with them, I had was able to observe how they spoke, and closely imitate everything they did. I would copy not only their way of speaking, but their body language too, because this is all part of effective communication.

Time spent with people, and imitating what they do, is the secret. 

So, if developing an effective accent is your goal, getting out of the house and interacting with people that you enjoy spending time with, becoming part of a community and using your language for a real purpose, should be something you prioritise.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a-FEVHpCbKg

This video addresses the question: "How can I learn a new language without putting in any desk time?" 

We've be conditioned to see language learning as an academic pursuit which requires us to sit down and hit the books.

But there's no reason at all it has to be like that. Focus on how you are using the language, making sure it's for authentic reasons - communication, reading, whatever interests you - and "desk time" doesn't have to be such a feature of your learning experience.

This is day 3 of my video marathon and I talk about how I learn grammar.

For me, grammar isn't something that should be the focus of your studies. It is important to learn grammar, but for beginners, most of what you want to express can be done through vocabulary and only a little grammar.

Learning of more complex patterns and structures can wait until you reach a pre-intermediate level.

title: Speaking Cantonese after 6 months - roast pork and dangerous driving!
description:
https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast â¬‡ï¸ GET MY FREE STORYLEARNINGÂ® KIT:
Discover how to learn any foreign language faster through the power of story with my free StoryLearningÂ® Kit ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼  https://bit.ly/freeslkit_learn-language-fast  

This is me (and my lovely assistant) speaking Cantonese after 6 months. As you can see, completely unprepared, and with the added complication of having to navigate the roads of Doha in my Jeep!

This video, for me, demonstrates what's possible by studying a language from scratch for 15-30 minutes a day. There were some days at the beginning where I did more, maybe 1 hour, but after the 2nd month, I've not been doing more than 30 mins a day, and often much less. I've also never spent any time in Hong Kong, until last week when I visited for a week. 

Cantonese is such a wonderful language! Obviously I'm not really doing it justice here with my ramblings, but it's full of expression, rich vocabulary, and lots of fun. I'm having more fun learning Cantonese than any other language since Brazilian Portuguese (and for very different reasons!).

However, easy it isn't. According to the US Foreign Service Institute, it's a Category V language (that's the highest, by the way!) - "Languages which are exceptionally difficult for native English speakers". As you can see, I'm still struggling with more complex sentences, and with my vocabulary which is fairly limited.

My learning strategy so far has involved a lot of input from listening (textbook audio and TV dramas), finding texts with audio (e.g. Complete Cantonese) and focusing primarily on building my vocabulary with the help of an SRS app. 

I began speaking fairly soon after starting, and I focused heavily on getting the tones right. (Any native speakers out there will be able to tell me if my tones are actually any good or not!). However, I didn't dive into having extended conversations with native speakers until the second or third month.

I also decided not to spend any time learning Chinese characters. This was a difficult, but conscious choice. I feel that if you've got limited time, and if you're motivated by speaking primarily, that there are more advantages to ditching Chinese characters at the beginning. The risk of diving right into Chinese characters, is that it occupies so much of your time that it is at the expense of progress in your speaking. That may not be a problem for you, but for me, it's the ability to speak which is the primary motivator for me, and I know that by progressing with my speaking, I'll start to build up a head of steam which will start a snowball effect in terms of motivation.

I discussed this very topic in a video interview recently, which you can find here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_V_JwzI1zjU&feature=share&list=UUSSLq4KYuztsj6ch2RbqoIg&index=1

Were I to go to live in Hong Kong (or China), I would probably start to need to learn Chinese characters quickly, but I would probably tackle it as a substantial project in its own right. [Note: I do actually already have a reasonably good knowledge of Chinese characters from Japanese, but it's nowhere near enough, so I feel the approach would still be valid for someone starting from zero; I basically haven't been reading or writing at all.] 

What's next? 

Well, there's a long way to go, and what I really need to do now is to continue building my vocabulary. That's priority number one. I plan to do that by a lot of listening and reading, and by having regular conversations with native speakers to keep improving my ability to put sentences together and express myself.

There are few good resources for Cantonese, but recently in Hong Kong I just found a really great book called "Living Cantonese for Intermediate Learners", which is comprised of an entire RTHK radio drama series, with transcriptions, vocab lists and explanations of grammar patterns included. So I'll be hitting that hard!

To follow my progress into the next 6 months don't forget to hit SUBSCRIBE, and visit my blog: http://iwillteachyoualanguage.com

description:

Stories are the best way I have found to learn Portuguese (and the 7 other languages I speak). Forget the boring textbooks and time-wasting apps! Learn Portuguese the natural, effective way with my Portuguese Uncovered course.
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ¼ https://bit.ly/portugueseuncoveredl1

Sign Up For Your Free Email Listening Course!
And discover the secret to understanding native speakers in any language, at any speed...http://learn.iwillteachyoualanguage.com/yt-optin-listening

For honest advice and practical tips for learning foreign languages visit: http://iwillteachyoualanguage.com

In this video I talk about how to learn Brazilian Portuguese. For me, Brazilian Portuguese has a number of interesting characteristics which make it a very approachable language, and one that isn't too difficult to learn. 

For example, the grammar is fairly straightforward for someone with English or a Romance language as their mother tongue. Brazilian culture is also very attractive to lots of people so once you get to know about Brazil and it's people, it's very easy to get absorbed into the Brazilian fold! 

In Brazil itself, I've met an unusually high number of native English speakers who learn to speak Portuguese to a pretty high level, which suggests that it really shouldn't been seen as a language that can't be learnt. 

All of this mean, for me, that there are lots of reasons to start speaking as soon as possible. I don't always recommend that - sometimes it's worth studying on your own for some time before starting to speak - however in the case of Brazilian Portuguese I think it's worth it, because it's relatively easy to pick up. 

However, there are some things to be wary of, not least the difference between Portuguese from Portugal and from Brazil, which are very different from one another. The accent, grammar and vocabulary in daily use, for example, are very different. I suggest making sure that any resources you have for learning are especially for Brazilian Portuguese, if that's what you want to learn.
